This end may be attained in various ways. The rules ol quantity should be learned gradually with the deelensions and conjuga- tions. To acquire them in this way adds little to the pupil's daily task3 while for one who has been allowed to pronounce carelessly until he enters college to attempt to reform his pro- nunciation ‚is an enormously difficult and discouraging labor3 it is really well-nigh hopeless. There is a close analogy in this respect with the use of correct English.

As not all quantities are determined by rule, but a great many · must be learned from memory and practice, it would seem a time-saving device to provide the pupil in the earlier stages oi his reading with a text in which the quantities are marked. · Having once learned to pronounce a word correctly, and having never been allowed to nzrtpronounce inl he is likely to continue to pronounce correctly when his texts are no longer marked, and to be led to look up for himself the quantity of words which are new to him. lt is in this belief that, throughout the book, the quantity of all long vowels has been marked. including ‘hidden quantities.'² ¹
